The correct answer is A. Secure variable storage.

Secure variable storage is a feature that is available only in Terraform Enterprise or Terraform Cloud workspaces, and it is not available in the Terraform CLI.

Secure variable storage allows you to store sensitive information, such as API keys, passwords, or other credentials, securely within Terraform. These variables are encrypted and protected, ensuring that they are not exposed in plain text.
Definitely A
A is correct answer. Terraform Cloud do provide secure storage for variables.
Answer is A, secure variable storage

A. Secure variable storage is available only in Terraform Enterprise or Cloud workspaces and not in Terraform CLI.

Terraform Enterprise and Cloud workspaces provide additional features and functionality beyond what is available in the open-source Terraform CLI. One of these features is the ability to store sensitive data, such as API keys or passwords, securely within a workspace. This allows teams to share infrastructure code without exposing sensitive information.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is available only in Terraform Enterprise or Cloud workspaces and not in Terraform CLI?
terraform init creates an example main.tf file in the current directory.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The terraform init command does not create an example main.tf file in the current directory. Its primary purpose is to initialize the working directory for Terraform configuration and set up the backend, providers, and modules specified in your configuration. It doesn't generate or modify any configuration files; you need to create your main.tf file yourself to define your infrastructure resources and settings.
b. False

C. version

The version argument helps prevent unexpected updates when calling Terraform Registry modules. It allows you to specify the exact version of the module you want to use. This ensures that your configuration consistently uses the same version of the module until you explicitly decide to update it to a newer version.

Using the version argument is a good practice to ensure that your infrastructure remains stable and predictable, as it prevents unintentional changes caused by automatic module updates.

Selected Answer: C
versioning is correct option.. agreed on Pete987

Selected Answer: C
agree Pete987
version is correct

Setting the TF_LOG environment variable to DEBUG causes debug messages to be logged into stdout.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B Because it's stdrr

Selected Answer: A
Setting the
TF_LOG
environment variable to
DEBUG
causes debug messages to be logged to standard output (stdout) or standard error (stderr)

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is:

âœ… A. True

Explanation:
Setting the TF_LOG environment variable to DEBUG causes Terraform to log debug-level messages into stdout (standard output). This is helpful for troubleshooting and understanding the inner workings of Terraform during execution.

Selected Answer: B
Setting the TF_LOG environment variable to DEBUG causes debug messages to be logged, but they are sent to the standard error (stderr) stream by default, not to standard output (stdout). To redirect or persist these logs, you can use additional configurations such as TF_LOG_PATH to specify a file for logging.

Selected Answer: B

questions.question_text: How would you output returned values from a child module in the Terraform CLI output?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer C
The question asks how to output the value in the cli, if we declare output only in a child module it will not be shown in the cli, we need one more output in the root configuration
this question is a replica of question 232. Answer given was B. Declare the output in the child module.

Selected Answer: B
n a parent module, outputs of child modules are available in expressions as module.<MODULE NAME>.<OUTPUT NAME>. For example, if a child module named web_server declared an output named instance_ip_addr, you could access that value as module.web_server.instance_ip_addr

Selected Answer: C
Looked this up on another testing engine ( O'Reilly ) and it has "C" as the correct answer.
question is weird.. If both in C become any it would be C

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. child>parent and parent>CLI

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. To print to the CLI it will also need to be declared in the root config

Selected Answer: B
There is no need to set the output in the root module.

Selected Answer: C
You can use outputs.tf in the child module and the output block in the root module.

B. Declare the output in the child module.

To output returned values from a child module in the Terraform CLI output, you need to declare the output in the child module. 

Option A, declaring the output in the root configuration, is incorrect because the output is defined in the child module. Option C, declaring the output in both the root and child module, is also incorrect because this would create duplicate outputs. Option D, none of the above, is incorrect because there is a way to output returned values from a child module in the Terraform CLI output.

comments.content: A child module can use outputs to expose a subset of its resource attributes to a parent module. A root module can use outputs to print certain values in the CLI output after running terraform apply .

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
1. To pass a value from child module to parent module, it must declare the output variable in child module.
2. To print out a value, it must declare the output variable in parent module.

comments.content: Thanks for the code. it worked. output should be defined in both parent and sub modules.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct answer

Selected Answer: B
In a parent module, outputs of child modules are available in expressions as module.<MODULE NAME>.<OUTPUT NAME>. For example, if a child module named web_server declared an output named instance_ip_addr, you could access that value as module.web_server.instance_ip_addr.

choices.A: Declare the output in the root configuration
choices.C: Declare the output in both the root and child module
choices.B: Declare the output in the child module
